long_title: Clinical Efficacy and Complications of Small-bore Versus Ultra-small Bore Chest Drain in Malignant Pleural Effusion: a Randomized Clinical Trial
prior_treatment_requirements: * Patients who have cytologically/histologically proven pleural malignancy, or who have pleural effusion in the context of malignancy elsewhere
* The pleural effusion is at least moderate to massive and causes symptoms
* Ability to give informed written consent to the study
Exclude - * Bleeding tendency not readily correctable (platelet \< 100 x 10\^9, INR ≥1.5 after transfusion)
Exclude - * Moderate-heavy septations in the pleural effusion (defined as a collection with more than 4 septations visible at the maximally septated area)
Exclude - * Clinical emergency that an urgent chest drain is required
Exclude - * Allergy to local anesthesia agents
Exclude - * History of pleurodesis on the same side of malignant pleural effusion requiring drainage
short_title: Comparing Different Sizes of Small-bore Chest Drains in Malignant Pleural Effusion
summary: Malignant pleural effusion (MPE) is a very common medical condition, especially among patients with disseminated cancers. Chest drain insertion aims to drain the pleural fluid collection and relieve dyspnea. Small bore chest tubes are recommended as the first line therapy for draining pleural effusions. However, there is no clinical data available to inform on the size of drains for better drainage. This is a randomized study comparing the two common bores of small bore chest drains in Hong Kong, and assess for its clinical efficacy and complication risks.
